The Department of State Authorities Act of 2006 may be cited as the short title for this Act. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The Department of State Authorities Act of 2006, also known as the short title for this Act, includes provisions for fraud prevention, education allowances, interference with protective functions, and extension of privileges and immunities. It also addresses personal services contracting, proliferation interdiction support, and the imposition of sanctions to deter the transfer of MANPADS. SEC. 3. EDUCATION ALLOWANCES. Section 5924(4) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include travel expenses for dependents to and from educational institutions. The amendment to Section 5924(4) of title 5, United States Code, allows for travel expenses for dependents to and from educational institutions, including allowances for storing baggage during one trip per year. SEC. 4. INTERFERENCE WITH PROTECTIVE FUNCTIONS. Offense.--Chapter 7 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding provisions regarding interference with protective functions. Sec. 118 states that any person who obstructs, resists, or interferes with a Federal law enforcement agent performing protective functions authorized by specific acts shall be fined or imprisoned for up to 1 year. SEC. 5 amends the Act of June 4, 1920 to excuse certain individuals from paying fees for passport issuance. SEC. 6 authorizes the Secretary of State to adjust surcharges for consular services supporting border security from fiscal year 2007 onwards. The Secretary of State is authorized to adjust surcharges for consular services supporting border security, ensuring that the amounts collected are related to the costs incurred for these services. The aggregate amount of surcharges collected cannot exceed the costs related to consular services for enhanced border security. SEC. 7. EXTENSION OF PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES.
    (a) The African Union.--Section 12 of the International 
Organizations Immunities Act (22 U.S.C. 288f-2) is amended to adjust surcharges for consular services supporting border security, ensuring that the amounts collected are related to the costs incurred for these services. The aggregate amount of surcharges collected cannot exceed the costs related to consular services for enhanced border security. The President is authorized to extend privileges and immunities to the African Union Mission and the Holy See, subject to corresponding conditions and obligations. SEC. 8. Removal of contracting prohibition under the Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act of 1986. SEC. 9. Amendment to personal services contracting in the Foreign Relations Authorization Act, Fiscal Year 2003. SEC. 10. Authorization for proliferation interdiction support to friendly foreign countries. The President must submit a report on proliferation detection and interdiction assistance to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report should detail the assistance provided by the Department of State to train and equip personnel in friendly foreign countries for detecting and intercepting proliferation-related shipments of weapons of mass destruction. The President must report on proliferation detection and interdiction assistance to Congress, detailing aid provided by the Department of State to detect and intercept proliferation-related shipments of weapons of mass destruction. Funding transfers and amendments to interdiction assistance programs are specified. The President is authorized to conclude agreements with other countries to prevent the transportation of weapons of mass destruction. The Secretary of State must notify Congress within 30 days of determining a country eligible for assistance. The Secretary of State is authorized to secure and eliminate conventional arms, including MANPADS and other weapons posing a proliferation threat located outside the US. This may involve humanitarian demining activities and securing or eliminating MANPADS and other weapons. The Secretary of State is authorized to secure and eliminate conventional arms, including MANPADS and other weapons posing a proliferation threat located outside the US. This involves assistance, cooperative programs, utilization of funds, and activities to secure and safeguard MANPADS and other conventional weapons. Actions are taken to ensure equipment and funds are used for authorized purposes. The policy of the United States is to hold foreign governments accountable for transferring MANPADS to state-sponsors of terrorism or terrorist organizations. If the President determines such transfers have occurred, a report must be submitted to the relevant congressional committees. The United States holds foreign governments accountable for transferring MANPADS to state-sponsors of terrorism or terrorist organizations. If the President determines such transfers have occurred, sanctions are imposed on the transferring foreign government, which is defined as a government that has repeatedly supported acts of international terrorism. The sanctions include termination of US Government assistance under various Acts. Sanctions may be imposed on a transferring foreign government under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, leading to termination of US Government assistance, including defense articles and military financing, unless waived by the President. The Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate states that providing assistance, sales, licensing, or financing that would be suspended due to sanctions is crucial for US national security interests. Definitions for terms like defense article, defense service, design and construction services, foreign government, and MANPADS are provided. SEC. 13. ADDITIONAL AUTHORITIES. This section amends the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2005 and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to increase war reserves stockpile and foreign assistance provisions. MANPADS are defined as surface-to-air missile systems portable by individuals or crews. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to increase funding from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 and extend loan guarantees to Israel until September 30, 2011. The amendment takes effect on August 5, 2006.
